div4.p: Clear & warm. No rain Gate opened to pass out Sick at 2 P.M. But only a Small portion of those who had been carried to the gate were taken out. My health is improving. I have Sold two buckets of bean soup to day & read 3 Chapters of Marks Gospel & 5 Chapters of the book of Proverbs.

div4.head: Saturday, August 6, 1864.
div4.p: Forenoon verry Sultry & hot Was engaged in Selling Soup on the Street to day but was quite unwell. A light Shower in the Evening a great deal of thunder & lightning at all points of the Comp=ass No roll call to day nor Sick Call a man Shot dead by one of the guards

div4.head: Sunday, August 7, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Clear & Warm a Hot day Throughout Read 10 Chapters in the book of Proverbs. Am Suffering greatly from Soreness in the legs & Swelling of the ankles am at a loss to know what it Can be.

div4.head: Monday, August 8, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Cloudy & Sultry Commenced Selling bean Soup this morning ag=ain. Heavy rain came up by 2 P.M. which continued till near Sundown, which cooled the air & done a great amount of good

div4.head: Tuesday, August 9, 1864.
div4.p: Cloudy & Cool & pleasant until 9 A.M. when it cleared & was followed by a Shower rain about noon. This was followed by another later in the afternoon one of the heav-iest I ever witnessed, which washed down the Stockade in some places & Caused quite a Stir among the rebels I was quite unwell to day

div4.head: Wednesday, August 10, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Cloudy & damp about 9 A.M. the sun Came out quite warm Had another heavy rain this after-noon, & also after night we passed a verry disagree=able night

div4.head: Thursday, August 11, 1864.
div4.p: Cloudy most of the forenoon Had a light Shower about noon afternoon pleasant with pleasant night I was verry unwell to day with Diarhea & pain in Stomach

div4.head: Friday, August 12, 1864.
div4.p: Cloudy most of the fore=noon. Clear & verry hot afternoon. I am very unwell to day Diarhea & Strong Symptoms of in=flamation of the Stomach & Bowells, feet much swollen

div4.head: Saturday, August 13, 1864.
div4.p: Nothing of note to day Verry Warm a light Shower about noon

div4.head: Sunday, August 14, 1864.
div4.p: Excessively hot. no rain I was not able to attend Roll=Call to day

div4.head: Monday, August 15, 1864.
div4.p: As hot as yesterday I was verry weak & Suffered greatly with pain in my Stomach & Bowels. From 2 or 3 P.M. it Clouded over & became more pleasant I feel much better this Evening, look much like rain

div4.head: Tuesday, August 16, 1864.
div4.p: Still verry hot. No news much better. Had a Shower just at dark

div4.head: Wednesday, August 17, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Clear & more pleasant than for Several days past. Nothing occurred worthy of note to day

div4.head: Thursday, August 18, 1864.
div4.p: A Bright hot day. I was verry unwell to day. To day I met Sergeant Lang of the 12th Indy "Vols" from Monticello Ind" from whom I learned that Capt" Brown was not dead as I last heard but was at Home wounded & that Lieut Bartholemew was dead

div4.head: Friday, August 19, 1864.
div4.p: Still quite hot to day. I am much better than yesterday. Had a light Shower of rain about 3 P.M.

div4.head: Saturday, August 20, 1864
div4.p: Verry Warm. Rain in the evening. Was verry unwell again to day A dreary Sabbath cleared up late in the Evening. No rain during the Night

div4.head: Sunday, August 21, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Cloudy & pleasant until 10 A.M. When it began to rain & continued Showers most of the day A dreary Sabbath Cleared up late in the Evening no rain during the night

div4.head: Monday, August 22, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Cloudy & verry Sultry Cleared off by 10 [-] A.M. & was one of the hottest days I have experienced in the Confederacy No rain to day. Was verry sick in the Evening

div4.head: Tuesday, August 23, 1864.
div4.p: Clear & verry warm but more pleasant than yes=terday

div4.head: Wednesday, August 24, 1864.
div4.p: Left the tent where I have been living for Some time past & have to Sleep out in the open air from this on

div4.head: Thursday, August 25, 1864.
div4.p: Verry hot to day & am quite unwell. Nothing else worthy of Note

div4.head: Friday, August 26, 1864.
div4.p: Still verry hot feel much better than for some time past hope I Shall be better{10}

div4.head: Wednesday, August 31, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Cloudy & Cool The Summer is Ended, and there is but little prospect of our deliverance as yet but I am thankful that my health is as good as what it is. I Still hope that God in his Kind Providence may Soon See fit to bring about that Event & So Relieve the Suf=fering of thousands besides my-self, & restore them & me to their families & Friends.

div4.head: Thursday, Sept. 1, 1864.
div4.p: Morning clear & beautiful, I feel pretty well this morning for which I am truly thank=ful{11}

div4.head: Wednesday, Sept. 7, 1864.
div4.p: Clear & verry warm. The long expected exchange commenced to day. Six Detachments have left to day for the point of exchange I have been verry unwell to day Sergt Lang of Monticello done me a favor by getting me a biscuit to day

div4.head: Thursday, Sept. 15, 1864.
div4.p: Left the Stockade late this evening in hopes of being off immediat=ely but from Some Cause they were delayed & we lay only at the Depot all Night

div4.head: Friday, Sept. 16, 1864.
div4.p: Morning Clear with promise of a hot day Still at the Depot at 8 A.M.

div4.head: MEMORANDA.
div4.p: {12}Was wounded on top of the head & in left Shoulder May 6th/64 at the battle of the "Wilder-ness" & taken prisoner by the Rebels.
May 12th Surgeon Bolton of the Confederate Service (But a Gentleman) extract=ed the ball from my Shoulder, A pretty Severe opperation as I did not take Chloroform

May 15th & 16th Marched from Field Hospital at Wilder=ness to Orange C. H. A Severe trip for me Arrived at the CH at 2 P.M. from thence was transported to Gordons Ville by R.R. where we arrived about five P.M.

div4.head: MEMORANDA.
div4.p: May 22nd 1864 Left Gordons Ville in Company with 223 other Wounded Soldiers & Officers at 1 P.M. & arrived at Linchburgh Va, & rested at the recieveing Hospital of that place

June 15th Was Discha=rged from the Hospital & Sent to the City Prison where I was Confined one Week June 22nd Were Started under guard by RR for Anderson Ville Ga June 28th Arrived at Camp Sumpter the Military Prison of the Confederate States about noon of the day

note.p: [ The following pages include distances and times by railroad from New York to thirty destinations including Richmond, Va. (18 ½ hours). Next is "A Complete Table of Stamp Duties", eclipses in 1864, moon phases for 1864, and tide tables for New York and San Francisco. The diary dates are pre-printed, one per page and in the transcription these dates appear in bold italics.
[The next six lines are not discernible.]
[Here begins, in italics, the diary entries of the unknown Indiana soldier.]
[He started to write "evening", but then wrote over it.]
[This is William H. Smith's last entry.]
[No further entries are made until June 15, 1865.]
[There are no entries from Sept. 2nd to 7th and from Sept. 8th to Sept. 15th.]]
[Here follow entries obviously made by the unknown Indiana soldier in the back of this diary:]
[The following may have been made by Wm. Smith.]
[Since this entry has to do with a pipe, a frequent reference of Smith's, this entry is probably his.]
[The following is written on the end papers.]
[On the last end paper are a self-made calendar of one month and the name and address of one man that is too faded to decipher as well as the following list of expenses.]
